Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.0; WOW64; rv:2.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/4.0

When you have filled the bookmarks toobar in such a way that it *just fits*, with no/little space to spare (assuming maximized window), things will fit fine when you startup firefox, because it will start with maximized window. But if you then resize the window and then maximize again, it will not fit anymore. The double-arrowed button (that lets you access non-fitting bookmarks) will appear to let you access the final bookmark (that does not fit anymore).

I think this is caused by the fact that the double-arrowed button appears when you resize the window, because then, it is necessary. But the button takes up space by itself as well! Then, if you maximize again, the available space is calculated, assuming the presence of the button and then, it will not fit anymore.

Solution: after a resize, always evaluate the available space pretending the button is not there (and hence does not take up extra space). Then, if it still does not fit, add button and evaluate again.

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Fill bookmarks toolbar in such a way that it *just fits*, with no/little space to spare in a maximized window
2. Resize the window, making the double-arrowed button appear
3. Maximize the window again.
Actual Results:  
Double-arrowed button will not dissapear and its presence causes its necessity, whereas it would not be necessary if it would not be present (because it takes up space itself)

Expected Results:  
Double-arrowed button should dissapear, making the bookmarks fit on the bar again.
